facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1274 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1274 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated November 23, 1965 in First Appeal No. 208 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 23, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 208 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant is a limited liability company incorporated under the English Companies Act with registered office at Lincoln, England.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited liability companypany incorporated under the English Companies Act with its registered office at Lincoln, England.

facts.text: Appellant carries on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal combustion engines and their parts and accessories.

anchor.surface_text: It carries on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal companybustion engines and their parts and accessories.

facts.text: Ruston Hornsby India Ltd. is a subsidiary of the appellant, registered in India under the Companies Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Ruston Hornsby  India  Ltd., a companypany registered in India under the Companies Act, 1956 is a subsidiary of the appellant.

facts.text: Ruston Hornsby India Ltd. is the registered user of the trade mark Ruston, registration No. 5120 in Class 7 for internal combustion engines.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a registered proprietor of the registered trade mark Ruston being registration No. 5120 in Class 7 in respect of internal companybustion engines.

facts.text: Ruston Hornsby India Ltd. manufactures and sells in India internal combustion engines under the trade mark RUSTON.

anchor.surface_text: Ruston and Hornsby  India  Ltd., is the registered user of the said trade mark and manufactures in India and sells in India internal companybustion.

facts.text: Respondent is a firm carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal combustion engines and their parts.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a firm carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of diesel internal companybustion engines and their parts.

facts.text: In June 1955, appellant learned that respondent was manufacturing and selling diesel internal combustion engines under the trade mark RUSTAM.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in June, 1955 the appellant came to. learn that the respondent was manufacturing- and selling diesel internal companybustion engines under the trade mark RUSTAM.

facts.text: On July 8, 1955, appellant wrote through its attorneys a letter to respondent calling upon it to desist from using RUSTAM as infringement of RUSTON.

anchor.surface_text: On July 8, 1955 the appellant wrote through its attorneys a letter to the respondent and called upon it to desist from using the trade mark RUSTAM on its. engines as it was an infringement of the registered trade mark RUSTON.

facts.text: Respondent replied that RUSTAM INDIA was not an infringement of RUSTON.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant replied that RUSTAM was number an infringement of RUSTON as the words RUSTAM INDIA was used.

facts.text: On February 17, 1956, appellant instituted a suit for permanent injunction restraining respondent from infringing trade mark RUSTON.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17, 1956 the appellant instituted a suit praying for a permanent injunction restraining the. respondent and its agents from infringing the trade mark RUSTON.

facts.text: On January 3, 1958, Additional District Judge, Meerut dismissed the suit holding no visual or phonetic similarity between RUSTON and RUSTAM.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1958 the Additional District Judge, Meerut, dismissed the suit holding that there was numbervisual or phonetic similarity between RUSTON and RUSTAM.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 208 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter in appeal in the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court by judgment dated November 23, 1965 held that use of RUSTAM by respondent constituted infringement of appellant's trade mark RUSTON.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated November 23, 1965 the High Court held that the use of the word RUSTAM by the respondent companystituted infringement of the appellants trade mark RUSTON and the respondent should be.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court permitted respondent to use RUSTAM INDIA as not an infringement because suffix India distinguishes engines manufactured in India from those in England.

anchor.surface_text: prohibited from using the trade mark RUSTAM. But the High Court proceeded to. hold that the use of the words RUSTAM INDIA was number an infringement because the plaintiffs engines were manufactured in England and the defendants engines were manufactured in India.

facts.text: Supreme Court found deceptive resemblance between RUSTON and RUSTAM.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the High Court has found that there is a deceptive resemblance between the word RUSTON and the word RUSTAM and therefore the use of the bare word ,RUSTAM companystituted infringement of the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON.

facts.text: Respondent did not appeal against High Court finding on RUSTAM infringement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has number brought an appeal against the judgment of the High Court on this point and it is, therefore, number open to. him to challenge that finding.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that addition of INDIA to RUSTAM does not prevent infringement.

anchor.surface_text: If the respondents trade mark is deceptively similar to. that of the appellant the fact that the word INDIA is added to the respondents trade mark is of numberconsequence and the appellant is enitled to succeed in its action.n for infringement of its trade mark.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and granted permanent injunction against use of RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in companynection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted nominal damages of Rs. 100/- to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is also. granted a decree for numberinal damages to the extent of Rs. 100/-

facts.text: Supreme Court ordered respondent to deliver price-lists, bills, invoices and advertising material bearing RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is further entitled to an order calling upon the respondent to deliver the appellant price-lists, bills, invoices and other advertising material bearing the mark RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 23, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 208 of 1958.

Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 states Subject to the provisions of section 22, 25 and 26 the registration of a person in the register as proprietor . of a trade mark in respect of any goods shall, give to .that person the exclusive right to. the use of the Trade mark in relation to those goods and, without prejudice to the generality of the ,foregoing provision, that right shall be deemed to be infringed by any person who, number being the proprietor of the trade mark or a registered user thereof using by way of the permitted use, uses a mark identical with it or so nearly resembling it as to be likely to deceive or cause companyfusion, in the companyrse of trade, in relation to any goods in respect of which it is registered, and in such manner as to render the use of the mark likely to be taken either--

concepts.interpretation: Registration gives exclusive right infringed by use of identical or nearly resembling mark likely to deceive or cause confusion; applied to hold RUSTAM and RUSTAM INDIA infringe RUSTON.

The distinction between an infringement action and a passing off action is important. Apart from the question as to. the nature of trade mark the issue in an infringement ,action is quite different from the issue in a passing off action. In a passing off action the issue is as follows . Is the defendant selling goods so marked as to be designed or calculated to lead purchasers to believe that they are the plantiffs goods ? But in an infringement action the issue is as follows Is the defendant using a mark which is the same as or which is a companyourable imitation of the plaintiffs registered trade mark ?

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished from statutory infringement; requires probability of confusion from get-up, no need for fraud; statutory infringement absolute if mark resembles.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between an infringement action and a passing off action is important. Apart from the question as to. the nature of trade mark the issue in an infringement ,action is quite different from the issue in a passing off action. In a passing off action the issue is as follows . Is the defendant selling goods so marked as to be designed or calculated to lead purchasers to believe that they are the plantiffs goods ? But in an infringement action the issue is as follows Is the defendant using a mark which is the same as or which is a companyourable imitation of the plaintiffs registered trade mark ?

arguments.claim: Statutory protection for registered marks is absolute; cannot escape infringement by distinguishing goods via elements outside the mark itself

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by the Master of the Rolls in Saville Perfumery Ltd. v. June Perfect Ltd. 2 . The Statute- law relating to infringement of trade marks is. based on the same fundamental idea as the law relating to passing-off. But it differs from that law in two particulars, namely  I   it is companycerned only with one method of passing-off, namely, the use of a trade mark, and  2  the statutory protection is absolute in the sense that once a mark is shown to offend, the user of it cannot escape by showing that by something outside the actual mark itself he has distinguished his goods from those of the registered proprietor.

arguments.claim: High Court finding of deceptive resemblance between RUSTON and RUSTAM cannot be challenged as respondent did not appeal

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has number brought an appeal against the judgment of the High Court on this point and it is, therefore, number open to. him to challenge that finding.

arguments.claim: If respondent's trade mark RUSTAM is deceptively similar to appellant's RUSTON, addition of INDIA does not prevent infringement

anchor.surface_text: If the respondents trade mark is deceptively similar to. that of the appellant the fact that the word INDIA is added to the respondents trade mark is of numberconsequence and the appellant is enitled to succeed in its action.n for infringement of its trade mark.

holdings.text: There is a deceptive resemblance between the word RUSTON and the word RUSTAM and therefore the use of the bare word RUSTAM constituted infringement of the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON. The respondent has not brought an appeal against the judgment of the High Court on this point and it is, therefore, not open to him to challenge that finding.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the High Court has found that there is a deceptive resemblance between the word RUSTON and the word RUSTAM and therefore the use of the bare word ,RUSTAM constituted infringement of the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON. The respondent has not brought an appeal against the judgment of the High Court on this point and it is, therefore, not open to him to challenge that finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding of deceptive resemblance accepted as final due to respondent's failure to appeal, binding under res judicata.

holdings.text: If the respondents trade mark is deceptively similar to that of the appellant the fact that the word INDIA is added to the respondents trade mark is of no consequence and the appellant is entitled to succeed in its action for infringement of its trade mark.

anchor.surface_text: If the respondents trade mark is deceptively similar to that of the appellant the fact that the word INDIA is added to the respondents trade mark is of no consequence and the appellant is entitled to succeed in its action for infringement of its trade mark.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deceptive similarity established; statutory protection under Trade Marks Act is absolute and addition of geographic descriptor outside the mark does not distinguish goods or avoid infringement, following Saville Perfumery precedent.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; appellant granted permanent injunction restraining respondents from infringing trade mark RUSTON or using RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA; nominal damages of Rs. 100/-; order for delivery up of infringing materials.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in connection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA. The appellant is also entitled to an injunction restraining the respondent and its agents from selling or advertising for sale of engines, machinery or accessories under the-name of RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA. The appellant is also granted a decree for nominal damages to the extent of Rs. 100/-. The appellant is further entitled to an order calling upon the respondent to deliver the appellant price-lists, bills, invoices and other advertising material bearing the mark RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of S.21 Trade Marks Act to facts: defendant's marks RUSTAM and RUSTAM INDIA are deceptively similar to plaintiff's RUSTON, constituting infringement warranting relief.

holdings.text: The statutory protection for registered trade marks is absolute in the sense that once a mark is shown to offend, the user cannot escape by showing that by something outside the actual mark itself he has distinguished his goods from those of the registered proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by the Master of the Rolls in Saville Perfumery Ltd. v. June Perfect Ltd. 2 . The Statute- law relating to infringement of trade marks is based on the same fundamental idea as the law relating to passing-off. But it differs from that law in two particulars, namely 1 it is concerned only with one method of passing-off, namely, the use of a trade mark, and 2 the statutory protection is absolute in the sense that once a mark is shown to offend, the user of it cannot escape by showing that by something outside the actual mark itself he has distinguished his goods from those of the registered proprietor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and applies English precedent (Saville Perfumery) to affirm absolute nature of infringement liability under Trade Marks Act, independent of external distinguishing features.

holdings.text: Where the alleged infringement consists of using not the exact mark on the Register, but something similar to it, the test of infringement is the same as in an action for passing off, namely the likelihood of confusion or deception arising from similarity of marks.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in considering the question of infringement the Courts have held, and it is not expressly provided by the Trade Marks Act, 1938, section 4, that infringement takes place not merely by exact imitation but by the use of a mark so nearly resembling the registered mark as to be likely to deceive. In an action for infringement where the defendants trade mark is identical with the plaintiffs mark, the Court will not enquire whether the infringement is such as is likely to deceive or cause confusion. But where the alleged infringement consists of using not the exact mark on the Register, but something similar to it, the test of infringement is the same as in an action for passing off in other words, the test as to likelihood of confusion or deception arising from similarity of marks is the same both in infringement and passing off actions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonizes statutory infringement test for similar marks with common law passing off test of likelihood of confusion, as per judicial interpretation and Act provisions.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in connection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA. The appellant is also entitled to an injunction restraining the respondent and its agents from selling or advertising for sale of engines, machinery or accessories under the-name of RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA. The appellant is also granted a decree for nominal damages to the extent of Rs. 100/-. The appellant is further entitled to an order calling upon the respondent to deliver the appellant price-lists, bills, invoices and other advertising material bearing the mark RUSTAM or RUSTAM INDIA.

We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in connection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA.

We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in connection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 provides the test for colourable imitation, addressing issue i1

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in considering the question of infringement the Courts have held, and it is not expressly provided by the Trade Marks Act, 1938, section 4, that infringement takes place not merely by exact imitation but by the use of a mark so nearly resembling the registered mark as to be likely to deceive. In an action for infringement where the defendants trade mark is identical with the plaintiffs mark, the Court will not enquire whether the infringement is such as is likely to deceive or cause confusion. But where the alleged infringement consists of using not the exact mark on the Register, but something similar to it, the test of infringement is the same as in an action for passing off in other words, the test as to likelihood of confusion or deception arising from similarity of marks is the same both in infringement and passing off actions.

We are accordingly of the opinion that this appeal should be allowed and the appellant should be granted a decree restraining the respondents by a permanent injunction from infringing the plaintiffs trade mark RUSTON and from using it in connection with the engines machinery and accessories manufactured and sold by it under the trade mark of RUSTAM INDIA.
